dt: {bc}social instability resulting from a breakdown of standards and values

dt.t: The reforms of a ruined economy, under these conditions, brought about social {wi}anomie{/wi}, desperation and poverty rather than relief and prosperity.

dt: {bc}personal unrest, alienation, and uncertainty that comes from a lack of purpose or ideals

dt.t: In the face of these prevailing values, many workers experience a kind of {wi}anomie{/wi}. Their jobs become empty, meaningless, and intrinsically unsatisfying.

et: French {it}anomie{/it}, from Middle French, from Greek {it}anomia{/it} lawlessness, from {it}anomos{/it} lawless, from {it}a-{/it} + {it}nomos{/it} law, from {it}nemein{/it} to distribute {ma}{mat|nimble|}{/ma}
shortdef: social instability resulting from a breakdown of standards and values; also : personal unrest, alienation, and uncertainty that comes from a lack of purpose or ideals
